title: 108_hr4640
content: The "District of Columbia Fairness in Representation Act" acknowledges the lack of voting representation for over half a million residents in the District of Columbia. Residents have a history of defending democracy and pay federal taxes, yet do not have direct representation in Congress. The Act aims to treat the District of Columbia as a congressional district. The "District of Columbia Fairness in Representation Act" recognizes the lack of voting representation for DC residents and aims to treat DC as a congressional district for House of Representatives purposes. Amendments are made regarding the apportionment method and appointments to service academies. Amendments are made to various sections of title 10, United States Code, to remove references to the District of Columbia. The changes apply to the One Hundred Ninth Congress and each succeeding Congress. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY INCREASE IN APPORTIONMENT OF HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. Effective January 3, 2005, the House of Representatives will temporarily increase its membership by 2 members until the first reapportionment after the 2010 census. The State identified by the Clerk of the House will receive an additional Representative. The President must transmit a revised apportionment statement to Congress within 30 days of the enactment of this Act. The President will send a revised apportionment statement to Congress to reflect the changes in the number of Representatives for each State. The Clerk of the House will then notify each State of the number of Representatives they are entitled to and report to the Speaker of the House. The President will send a revised apportionment statement to Congress to reflect changes in the number of Representatives for each State. A report will be submitted to the Speaker of the House of Representatives identifying the State entitled to one additional Representative. The temporary increase in House membership will not affect the permanent membership or the basis of reapportionment for future Congresses. It will also not impact the number of electors for the 2004 Presidential election. SEC. 5. REPEAL OF OFFICE OF DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA DELEGATE. The District of Columbia Delegate Act is repealed, restoring laws as if the act had not been enacted. Amendments are made to the District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955, removing references to the Delegate to Congress. The District of Columbia Delegate Act is repealed, removing references to the Delegate to Congress in various sections of the District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955. The District of Columbia Delegate Act is repealed, removing references to the Delegate to Congress in the District of Columbia Elections Code of 1955. The amendments made by this section shall apply to elections in 2004 and beyond. SEC. 6. REPEAL OF OFFICE OF STATEHOOD REPRESENTATIVE. Amendment to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979 to change references from "Representative" to "Senator" and remove mentions of the Representative's office in various subsections. Amendment to the District of Columbia Statehood Constitutional Convention Initiative of 1979 includes changes to the Statehood commission and authorization of appropriations. Amendments to D.C. laws regarding honoraria limitations and campaign finance laws are made, affecting elections from 2004 onwards. SEC. 7. NONSEVERABILITY OF PROVISIONS: If any provision of this Act or any amendment made by this Act is held invalid, the remaining provisions shall also be invalid.
